title: Report Reveals Call Records Between Giuliani, White House and Nunes
summary: Draft impeachment report shows president's lawyer and top Republican lawmaker in frequent contact. WASHINGTON-Call records obtained by impeachment investigators revealed new details about Rudy Giuliani's interactions with the White House, his associates and Rep. Devin Nunes, the top Republican on the House Intelligence Committee.

title: Elon Musk Takes the Stand in Defamation Lawsuit
summary: Tesla CEO defends his comment, saying it wasn't meant literally. LOS ANGELES-Elon Musk told a Los Angeles jury that a Twitter message he sent last year suggesting a man in Thailand was a pedophile wasn't, in fact, meant to connotate a dictionary definition of the word and was written in response to what he viewed as an unprovoked attack.

title: Requiem for a Climate Dream
summary: If the world isn't slashing CO2, blame overreaction to the Fukushima disaster.. Rigor could be restored to mainstream climate journalism with a single clause. That clause consists of the words "if climate models are accurate."

title: Polarized America Still Has a Big Middle
summary: In a new poll, 43% identify with the center, including 60% of independents.. In this era of intense partisan polarization, it might seem odd-even quaint-to speak of a "center" of American politics. But a soon-to-be-released survey from the New Center, a bipartisan policy institute I helped start, suggests this term applies, albeit incompletely, to today's American public. Both political parties ignore this center at their peril.

title: 'The Cartiers' Review: Never Copy, Only Create
summary: For devotees of jewelry, the Cartier magic has something to do with a subtle mix of old and new, timeless elegance and hints of Parisian style.. Francesca Cartier Brickell was visiting her grandfather when she discovered in his cellar a trunk of letters long thought lost. Together, the two began reading this trove of correspondence and unraveling their family's history, beginning with Ms. Cartier Brickell's great-great-great-grandfather, Louis-François Cartier, who in 1847 founded the family's eponymous jewelry business in Paris. The result is "The Cartiers," the tale of a clan united in single-minded dedication to the success of their enterprise, with walk-on parts from the world's most glamorous princesses, heiresses and maharajas.

title: Brad Pitt and a Father-Daughter Moment
summary: The actor played a part in the elderly man's memory check.. 'Do you know who this is, Dad?" a woman who appeared to be in her 50s said, with some concern in her voice, to the elderly man sitting next to her. They were in a doctor's waiting room. In front of the man's knees was a metal walker.

title: New York App Firm Urges Reclassifying Gig Workers
summary: Household-help company suggests an hourly threshold for full-time status. As New York lawmakers prepare legislation to regulate the state's gig economy, one app company has pitched reclassifying workers who put in at least 25 hours a week as full-time employees.

title: Banks No Longer Required to Report Hemp Growers as Suspicious, Regulators Say
summary: A group of financial regulators said lenders are no longer required to file reports on customers who produce hemp for commercial purposes. Banks are no longer required to file suspicious activity reports on customers who cultivate hemp, industry regulators said.

title: New York State Lawmakers in No Rush to Tweak Campaign Finance Plan
summary: A commission's recommendations on how parties and campaigns operate will become law on Dec. 22 unless they are changed or rejected. ALBANY-New York state Assembly Speaker Carl Heastie said Tuesday he wasn't alarmed by any of a state panel's controversial recommendations to overhaul how elections are conducted, rebuffing calls that lawmakers take action before the recommendations go into effect laterthis month.

title: Why Our Students Objected to Mac Donald
summary: At Holy Cross education sometimes means engaging speakers with controversial messages, as with Ms. Mac Donald. And sometimes, it means making use of their own free speech to combat objectionable ideas.. As dean of students at the College of the Holy Cross, I can certainly agree with Heather Mac Donald ("Why Are College Students So Afraid of Me?," op-ed, Nov. 27) on one point: College students are generally among the most privileged people in the world. At Holy Cross, students learn to use that privilege to make the world a better place. That education requires them to wrestle with a wide range of ideas, which sometimes means engaging speakers with controversial messages, as with Ms. Mac Donald. And sometimes, it means making use of their own free speech to combat objectionable ideas.

title: Fed Adds $95.56 Billion in Short-Term Liquidity to Markets
summary: Central bank is using temporary operations to tamp down any possible wild moves. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York added $95.56 billion in temporary liquidity to financial markets Tuesday.

title: Give Bloomberg News Credit for Transparency
summary: At least they are telling us the ground rules and we are forewarned that their coverage is biased.. I must take exception to your editorial "Bloomberg No News" (Nov. 26). Rather than criticize Bloomberg LP editors for instituting a policy under which the news organization will only "investigate" President Trump and give Mike Bloomberg and other Democratic candidates a free pass, we should applaud their transparency. At least they are telling us the ground rules and we are forewarned that their coverage is biased. No other major news organization has made such a statement about its coverage, though in practice most do exactly the same while claiming to offer balanced reporting.

title: Idea Laundering Portends The Future Thought Police
summary: I regularly witness how this proselytizing has influenced educators, many of whom are graduates of programs that prize ideology over technical knowledge and criticism over solutions.. Peter Boghossian's criticism of "'Idea Laundering' in Academia" (op-ed, Nov. 25) is accurate and well explains a process best characterized as borderline unethical. During my doctoral program, I sat in several classes that were filled with such ideologically driven faculty and their sycophants who were only too eager to muse about how the problems of urban schooling could be solved with one critical theory or another. And while this agenda has undoubtedly propelled many to tenure, academics are largely immune to its effects.

title: China Industrial Complex, Monopoly and U.S. Security
summary: While I agree with Mr. Chertoff's arguments about the fear of monopoly and the importance of innovation, I implore him to take a look at the woeful tale of our country's abandonment of the lead we once had in wireless technology.. I'll start by noting that I don't own any Qualcomm stock, and I doubt that Michael Chertoff does ("Qualcomm's Monopoly Imperils National Security," op-ed, Nov. 25). While I agree with Mr. Chertoff's arguments about the fear of monopoly and the importance of innovation, I implore him to take a look at the woeful tale of our country's abandonment of the lead we once had in wireless technology. Bell Labs, Motorola and a host of other world-class companies weren't protected by the U.S. when they were attacked by companies which were protected by their home government. Let's not repeat this American tragedy. It is imperative that we protect Qualcomm, our country's last mobile-chip manufacturer.

title: The Prickly John Simon Was Very Sure of His Views
summary: I was glad to see the late John Simon fondly remembered in your Nov. 26 "Notable & Quotable" column. But let us not forget his dogmatic side.. I was glad to see the late John Simon fondly remembered in your Nov. 26 "Notable & Quotable" column. But let us not forget his dogmatic side. Before starting his brilliant career as a drama critic, he was an instructor of English at the University of Washington. But his teaching career there was short-lived because he ran up against a chairman named Robert Heilman, who didn't tolerate instructors who used the expression "my course." In 1955 a delegation from Simon's class on American prose complained to Heilman that Simon was teaching only American poetry because, so he told them, "American prose is no good."

title: Mexico Resists Democrats' Labor Push on Trade Pact
summary: Opposition in Mexico puts the new North American trade accord at risk of not passing before the 2020 U.S. election. Mexico's government and business leaders are voicing opposition to a key demand of U.S. Democratic lawmakers in a renegotiated North American trade pact, jeopardizing the deal's passage this year.

title: U.S. Exempts Venezuela's Baseball League From Sanctions
summary: The move potentially paves the way for players affiliated with Major League Baseball to participate despite U.S.-imposed economic sanctions against the South American country. Venezuela's baseball league has received a license from the U.S. Treasury that potentially paves the way for players affiliated with Major League Baseball to participate despite U.S.-imposed economic sanctions against the South American country.

title: Google Needed to Bow to Convention
summary: Alphabet's leadership change clears up confusing structure. Google has long prided itself on being unconventional. But some conventions are good-including having a boss that can be seen on occasion.

title: Google's Founders Give Up Top Jobs
summary: Google CEO Sundar Pichai will now lead search giant's parent, Alphabet, becoming one of Silicon Valley's most powerful figures. Google co-founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin stepped down from active management of the internet giant's parent, surrendering immediate control to a low-key company veteran who must navigate global regulatory threats as well as employee discontent.

title: New York City Sued Over Program That Relocates Homeless
summary: Program provides one year's full rent up front for eligible shelter residents to move to anywhere in the U.S.. The city of Newark, N.J., has filed a lawsuit against New York City and its mayor, Bill de Blasio, over a program that has relocated thousands of New York's homeless-shelter residents to municipalities across the country.

title: Italy's UniCredit to Cut 8,000 Jobs, Launch Buyback
summary: Cost-cutting plan by Italy's biggest bank comes as low rates, stringent regulation and greater U.S. competition dent European lenders' profits. LONDON-Italy's largest bank, UniCredit SpA, ruled out targeting big acquisitions as it pledged share buybacks and dividend increases, part of a four-year plan that also includes cuts in jobs and costs.

title: Sharp Drop Ends Recent Tranquility in the Stock Market
summary: Tuesday's decline in the Dow industrials ends a 38-session streak without a fall of at least 1%. The stock market appears to be breaking out of its recent lull.

title: Lands' End Shares Jump on Earnings, Cold Weather
summary: Still, the clothing retailer's stock price is roughly flat for the year. Chilly weather across much of the U.S. has boosted Lands' End Inc. stock, which was a rare bright spot in the markets on Tuesday.

title: U.S. Stocks Fall After Trump Signals Further Delays to China Deal
summary: President Trump says he has 'no deadline' for a trade agreement with China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average suffered its biggest single-day pullback since early October on Tuesday after President Trump suggested the trade war with China could continue well into next year.

title: Harvard Student Workers Go on Strike
summary: Graduate Students Union, Ivy League school at odds over contract terms including pay, benefits. Graduate-student workers at Harvard University went on strike after they were unable to reach agreement with the Ivy League school over contract issues including pay, health coverage and protections against sexual harassment and discrimination.

title: Fidelity's Asset-Management Chief to Retire in February
summary: Boston financial firm names Bart Grenier to succeed Steve Neff as head of asset-management unit. Fidelity Investments' asset-management chief will retire in February, the latest leadership change at a business under pressure to adapt to investors' preference for lower-cost funds.

title: Twitter Plans First Sale of High-Yield Debt
summary: The social-media company aims to raise $600 million as it tries to bounce back from disappointing third-quarter earnings. Twitter Inc. is marketing its first-ever unsecured bonds, aiming to raise $600 million as it tries to bounce back from disappointing third-quarter earnings.

title: NSA to Issue Updated Cloud Security Guidance
summary: Intelligence agency to detail methods that nation-state hackers use to compromise companies. The National Security Agency plans to issue updated guidance to companies on cybersecurity in the cloud, a senior official said, amid a series of attacks that have targeted service providers in recent months.

title: Trump Clashes With Macron on NATO, Trade and Islamic State
summary: Two leaders have testy public encounter at summit marking the alliance's 70th anniversary. LONDON-President Trump and French President Emmanuel Macron clashed openly over tariffs, the treatment of Islamic State terrorists and NATO's priorities at a gathering to celebrate the alliance's 70th anniversary.

title: Good U.S. Economy Isn't a Given for 2020
summary: Persistent trade tensions could puncture complacency about the economy. So much for that easing of trade worries.

title: Oil Trading in Sweet Spot Adds to Improving Economic Signals
summary: Oil prices settle in range that analysts say benefits large energy producers and consumers. Oil prices have stayed in a contained range that analysts say benefits both producers and consumers, bolstering hopes that the global economy can rebound.

title: Wyndham Hotels Promotes Finance Exec to CFO Amid Post-Spinoff Growth Push
summary: Michele Allen, the company's treasurer, succeeds David Wyshner, who helped lead spinoff and La Quinta deals. Wyndham Hotels & Resorts Inc. has promoted a financial executive to finance chief as the company eyes the next phase of growth following a spinoff from its parent last year.

title: A Fact-Packed Guide to the Surprisingly Complicated Sock
summary: Are expensive socks worth it? How do you fix a sock hole? Do any men wear garters anymore? The answer to these and many other burning questions about humble hosiery. Probably cave men. "The cave man was smart enough to know that if you took an animal skin and you wrapped it around your feet...that kept you warm," said Steven Frumkin, Dean of the Jay and Patty Baker School of Business and Technology at the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York. In 1991, "Otzi the Iceman," a Copper-Age hunter preserved in the icy Otzal Alps for about 5,000 years, was discovered alongside socks made of hay and cage-like shoes. In the 1800s, stitched socks with cartoonishly long, bifurcated toes were excavated in Egypt. They're believed to date from the 3rd to the 5th century and were the precursors to socks we wear today.

title: Amazon Introduces 'Plug and Play' AI Tools
summary: Company's cloud customers will be able to use two new services to glean insights from disparate data. Amazon. com Inc. on Tuesday introduced two artificial-intelligence services designed to help companies gain better insight from business data spread across multiple sources, from documents to conversations with customers.

summary: Two shows offer very different approaches to exploring African-Americans' contributions to modernism.. Baltimore and Hartford, Conn.

summary: Futures climbed after some models predicted a sweep of cold weather across the Midwest and eastern two-thirds of the U.S.. The price of natural gas rose on Tuesday, buoyed by expectations for colder weather in the coming weeks that could boost demand for the fuel.

title: Chicago Mayor Fires Police Chief, Says He Lied
summary: Superintendent, under investigation for falling asleep in his patrol car, had planned to step down at end of year. CHICAGO-Mayor Lori Lightfoot fired the city's outgoing police superintendent Monday, saying he lied to her and committed "intolerable" ethical lapses over an incident in which he was found asleep in his police car.

summary: Asian students remain far ahead of Americans; performance gap widens domestically. U.S. teenagers made no significant gains on an exam taken by students around the world, and continue to trail students in Asian countries.

summary: Overall vehicle sales in November were expected to be up from a year ago, according to industry analysts. title: Barney McCallum Joined Two Friends to Invent Pickleball
summary: Printer and handyman refined paddles for fast-growing sport with a baffling name. On Bainbridge Island, near Seattle, Barney McCallum was known as a handyman. So two of his neighbors, Joel Pritchard and William Bell, asked him to help refine a game they invented in 1965 as a diversion for bored children.

summary: Tony Kushner's 1985 history play prefigured 'Angels in America,' but even a new revival leaves a lot to be desired..

summary: The Facebook-owned app wants more athletes, teams and leagues to offer products directly on its platform. Sports stars, teams and leagues have long used Instagram to promote themselves and build relationships with fans. Increasingly, they're using it to sell products, too.

summary: Full Senate is expected to vote on Stephen Hahn's nomination by the end of December. WASHINGTON-A Senate committee voted 18-5 to approve the nomination of radiation oncologist and hospital executive Stephen Hahn to become commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Three Generations, and No Agreement on Going Cashless
summary: One family, three generations and no agreement on the shift away from cash. When Oliver Hicks finished helping his family with yard work last summer, his dad handed him $50 in cash. Oliver didn't want it. He asked his dad to send him the money through an app on his phone.

summary: Investigation by state utilities commission concludes company failed to properly inspect and maintain transmission lines for years. PG&E Corp. failed to adequately inspect and maintain its transmission lines for years before a faulty line started the deadliest fire in California history, a state investigation has found.

BEIJING-China suspended visits by U.S. military ships and aircraft to Hong Kong and placed sanctions on some U.S. nongovernment organizations, in an act of retaliation against President Trump's signing of a bill intended to show support for Hong Kong's antigovernment protesters.

title: Trump to Put Tariffs on Brazil, Argentina, Citing Currencies
summary: President accuses both countries of manipulating their currencies to devalue them, but few economists agree. President Trump said Monday he would raise tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from Brazil and Argentina, surprising financial markets and opening a new front in the global trade war.

title: Senate Republicans Push New Privacy Initiative
summary: Mississippi's Wicker, chair of Senate Commerce panel, wants to avoid patchwork of conflicting state laws on privacy. WASHINGTON-Senate Republicans are prepared to support tough new protections for consumer data in hopes of salvaging efforts to adopt a national privacy law, Commerce Committee chairman Sen. Roger Wicker (R., Miss.) said Monday.

title: Spooked by China, Australia's Spies Pursue New Bonds
summary: Effort will pool intelligence information, as authorities grow concerned about Beijing's activities. SYDNEY-Australia is creating a new intelligence task force to tackle the threat of foreign interference, as authorities grow more concerned that Beijing is meddling in domestic affairs.

title: Trump Administration Proposes Tariffs on $2.4 Billion of French Goods
summary: Move is in response to France's digital-services tax. The Trump administration proposed tariffs of up to 100% against $2.4 billion of French imports, saying the nation's new digital-services tax unfairly targets U.S. tech companies such as Apple Inc. and Alphabet Inc.'s Google unit.

title: Fundraising by Parent Associations in New York City Varies by School
summary: Data released for first time by city shows disparity across schools. While parent associations at some New York City public schools scrape together a few hundred dollars a year, others raise hundreds of thousands of dollars in donations that pay for arts programs, librarians and field trips.

title: Broadway Sales Spike Over Thanksgiving, but Decline From 2018
summary: 'Moulin Rouge!,' 'Beetlejuice' and 'Tina' set individual highs for weekly grosses. Thanksgiving week proved to be a record-breaking one for some shows on Broadway but not for the industry overall.

title: To Battle Passive Funds, Active Investors Shun Diversification
summary: Stock pickers are making more concentrated bets, hoping to distinguish themselves from passively managed, diversified index funds. Trouble is, the results haven't been great.. Conventional investing wisdom holds that the safest portfolios are highly diversified and spread across a considerable number of assets. But that isn't stopping plenty of stock pickers from running in the opposite direction.

title: House GOP Report Defends Trump in Impeachment Probe
summary: Lawmakers seek to counter Democrats over president's hold on security aid and request that Ukraine investigate U.S. political rival. WASHINGTON-House Republicans offered a harsh assessment of the impeachment inquiry, saying in a report that Democrats hadn't proven that President Trump pressured Ukraine to initiate investigations in an effort to benefit his 2020 re-election bid, and that his hold on nearly $400 million in security assistance and a White House meeting was "entirely prudent."

title: Never Mind the Bullock
summary: But plenty of voters still want a moderate Democrat for President.. Montana's Steve Bullock, a two-term governor from a conservative state, has quit the race for the Democratic presidential nomination. But his exit doesn't mean Democratic primary voters aren't shopping for a moderate candidate. A new poll out Monday suggests Democrats are still more interested in beating Donald Trump than in fomenting socialist revolution.

title: Senate Confirms Former Lobbyist Dan Brouillette as Energy Secretary
summary: Vote of 70-15 is in contrast to the extreme partisanship characterizing other cabinet-nominee approvals. WASHINGTON-The Senate confirmed Dan Brouillette as energy secretary, putting another former advocate for business interests in charge of the Trump administration's energy policy.

title: Mount Tariff Erupts Again
summary: Trump hurts his re-election chances with more trade uncertainty.. Just when you think President Trump has reached a moment of trade equilibrium, there he goes again. Mount Tariff erupted once more Monday morning in tweets announcing tariffs on Brazilian and Argentine steel that dampened hope for election-year economic calm.

title: Of Gun Rights and a Cup of Coffee
summary: Never trust a politician in New York on the Second Amendment.. Can the U.S. Supreme Court trust the politicians of New York City to protect the Second Amendment? Believe it or not, that question consumed the biggest chunk of Monday's oral argument in the first gun rights case the Justices have heard in 10 years. The answer is no, and the lawyer for the city proved the point during oral argument.

title: Pelosi Will Always Have Paris
summary: 'We're still in,' the Speaker tells the U.N. climate conference.. President Trump didn't jet off to Madrid for this week's United Nations climateklatsch, but Nancy Pelosi brought a congressional delegation-and a message. "By coming here," she proclaimed at a news conference, "we want to say to everyone: We're still in. The United States is still in."
